overview_of_class:
From Euripides' Medea to Shakespeare's Richard III, from Travis Bickle to Tony Soprano, some of the greatest characters in Western drama have been those who subvert or complicate the simple dichotomy of good vs. evil. In this class, we will read plays and screenplays that feature the most memorable of antiheroes and sympathetic villains. We will examine the uses (and misuses) of empathy, study how the ethical orientation of central characters impacts a script's plot and structure, and learn how to write our own compelling and morally ambiguous characters.

There will be weekly reading and writing assignments, and each student will complete a treatment and roughly 30 pages of a new play, screenplay, or teleplay.

subject: RTVF

overview_of_class:
In this class, we will investigate the complicated relationship between truth and fiction by researching and writing our own "fact-based" dramatic scripts. From the "living newspapers" of the 1930's to today's "verbatim theatre," from documentary film to narrative drama "based on a true story," non-fiction can provide dramatists with a rich vein of material and raise fascinating issues about the differences between historical and artistic "truth."

There will be weekly reading assignments, and each student will assemble an original portfolio of fact-based sources (historical research, contemporary interviews, photographs and video footage, etc.) and write at least 30 pages of a new play, film, or television script (narrative or documentary) drawn from that non-fiction material.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course will explore: What are some of the current issues facing the LGBTQIA community that are seen on social media? Which of the groups within this community are the most underrepresented? Where is LGBTQIA headed in terms of television/theater/web series, and what could the future hold? How do I tell a story that centers around LGBTQIA characters using the context of theatre, TV or web?

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Besides writing a pilot, play, or web content, students will also: prepare pitches and short critical papers around the material covered.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Articles, Skype talks, Media clips, and scripts which will be provided

Class notes: Access to a laptop and script writing software is important in this course and will not be provided.

overview_of_class: This is a performance class for writers. Writers in performance will learn the improvisation techniques that translate to successful creative careers in film and television, such as: deeper understanding of the interior of scenes; pacing, character, heightening, "game of the scene" and dialogue. In the second part of our class we put these skills together in longer forms as a way to study story structure. As a class we will attend an improv show in Chicago.

overview_of_class: Writers rarely set out to write in a particular literary mode when they begin a project, but a thorough knowledge of such modes not only helps an artist define the tone and point of view of a piece, it also encourages artistic exploration.  This class will examine a variety of stylistic modes including Naturalism, Expressionism, Surrealism, and Epic Theatre.  We will analyze examples of each style from film and theatre. Through readings, screenings of films, lectures, and discussion, we will examine the historical context of each mode, and the ways in which certain artists have created works which are both grounded in historical styles and highly original.  Each student will then write a short screenplay or play in each style.  These short pieces will lead to the development of a final project: the first thirty pages and complete outline of a full-length screenplay or play.
